title: Barracouta Fishing In Tasmania
subject_group: Anthropology, Ethnology, Exploration & Travel/Tasmania - Description and travel
Anthropology, Ethnology, Exploration & Travel/Tasmania - Social life and customs
abstract: A short silent film made around 1929 documenting a trip by the Tasmanian Sea Fisheries' Board patrol boat 'Allara'.
description: Allara's skipper, Tom Challenger takes us from Hobart to Storm Bay where a barracouta fishing fleet is at work. The boat sails down the Derwent River and rounds the 'Iron Pot' beacon at the mouth of the Derwent River. Barracouta are caught landing on the deck of a boat using a jig attached to a pole. The fish are then cleaned and filleted. The site for a proposed factory at Parsons Bay to process barracouta for stock feed and oil is shown, and proposed methods of catching the barracouta with trawl and purse-seine nets is also illustrated with diagrams. Source: NFSA
part_of_compliation_title_or_vod_package: VoD Program; B2002943; A Tasmanian Time Capsule; Active; 2014
